docs.lead_paragraph: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.
docs.abstract: The United States stands out as one of the few rich nations in the world that doesn't mandate any form of paid sick leave, an economist writes.
docs.snippet: The United States stands out as one of the few rich nations in the world that doesn't mandate any form of paid sick leave, an economist writes.

docs.lead_paragraph: As if to punctuate that talk of bipartisanship goes only so far, Republicans voted to block a nominee shortly after a meeting with the president.

docs.lead_paragraph: An eye-popping increase in health insurance premiums in California has become a White House talking point. Anthem Blue Cross, which is California's largest for-profit health insurer, plans to raise its rates for customers who buy individual coverage by as much as 39 percent by March 1, according to a recent report in The Los Angeles Times.
docs.abstract: Anthem Blue Cross, California's largest for-profit health insurer, plans to raise its rates for customers who buy individual coverage by as much as 39 percent by March 1; Pres Obama cites Anthem's move as example of why Congress needs to change health care system; Health and Human Services Sec Kathleen Sebelius demands that Anthem publicly justify increases (M)
docs.snippet: An eye-popping  increase in health insurance premiums in California has become a White House talking point.     Anthem Blue Cross, which is California's largest for-profit health insurer, plans to raise its rates for customers who buy individual...

docs.lead_paragraph: To many Americans who watched the Democrats' family feud over the last few months, it might have seemed as if Republicans were more unified on health care. One luxury of being the minority party in Congress is the ability to avoid having internal disagreements in the spotlight. In reality, Republicans generally do not speak with a single voice on health care policy, any more than Democrats do. Consider the tax treatment of employer-sponsored health benefits.
docs.abstract: Republicans are no more united on issue of health care legislation than Democrats are; Sen John McCain proposes ending tax exclusion of employer-sponsored health benefits and replacing it with uniform tax credit; Rep Dave Camp is opposed to ending exclusion, saying it would be too disruptive; photos (M)
docs.snippet: To many Americans who watched the Democrats' family feud over the last few months, it might have seemed as if Republicans were more unified on health care. One luxury of being the minority party in Congress is the ability to avoid having internal...

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, sharply criticized Anthem Blue Cross of California on Tuesday over its plans to raise health insurance premiums by as much as 39 percent, and she said that the move provided a vivid example of why major health care legislation is needed.

headline.main: Feinstein Blasts Calif. Insurer Over Rate Increase

docs.abstract: The senator from California excoriates an insurance company for an "unconscionable" rate hike.
docs.snippet: The senator from California excoriates an insurance company for an "unconscionable" rate hike.

docs.lead_paragraph: House Democrats, seeking to move forward with at least a component of their health care legislation, had planned to vote this week on a bill to repeal the limited exemption from federal antitrust laws long enjoyed by insurance companies. But after a huge snowstorm over the weekend, and with another one rolling in on Tuesday afternoon, the House canceled all votes this week.
docs.abstract: House Democrats were forced on Tuesday to cancel a vote on the insurance industry's antitrust exemption.
docs.snippet: House Democrats were forced on Tuesday to cancel a vote on the insurance industry's antitrust exemption.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama declared today that "a sense of purpose that transcends petty politics" must be forged by Democrats and Republicans to create more jobs, reduce the deficit and find at least some common ground on health care.
docs.abstract: The president stopped into the White House briefing room to talk about his meetings with leaders of both parties.
docs.snippet: The president stopped into the White House briefing room to talk about his meetings with leaders of both parties.

byline.original: By JEFF ZELENY and HELENE COOPER

docs.lead_paragraph: There is nothing like plans for new bipartisanship to create an argument over, well, bipartisanship.
docs.abstract: Democrats and Republicans have something new to argue about: who's really interested in bipartisanship.
docs.snippet: Democrats and Republicans have something new to argue about: who's really interested in bipartisanship.
